I tried watching almost immediately after the doc (a few days) and everything seemed so over dramatized in comparison.
That rings true to me. I had no issue watching the doc after the FX series; I'd probably recommend that route.

Getting this out of the way: the dude knocked a girl half his size out cold. I don't care what the surrounding circumstances are. That's a problem. I don't see how investigating, hoping to be able to say with a straight face, "Well she provoked him, so it isn't as bad as it looks," does anyone any good, most of all the player.
As far as I'm concerned any investigation should be directed at gauging how remorseful the player is, adn more importantly, what he has done and is currently doing to get help. Make your decision on whether you can handle his character issues based on that.
How can they best get the player (and victim, if DV) help, and create a workplace environment to foster that. UNDERSTAND THE ISSUE. And that it *is* an issue; don't make excuses for the player. The logistics, well, that's above my expertise, but it's clear the league and its teams aren't doing a great job at that right now, and that probably has something to do with excuse-making and the fact that all this shit is just a PR game to them.
P.S. Interesting link: http://deadspin.com/zero-tolerance-for-domestic-violence-will-only-make-it-1787428167
edit: clarity
Anything is better than the zero tolerance rage that defined this discourse for so long.

I think this is now the majority opinion. The public stance has really shifted on this stuff, it seems. It went from zero tolerance for a while, and lately swung all the way to the other end of the pendulum, perhaps too far so.

Everyone can look at the video and see exactly what happened, but what we really don't know are what were the circumstances around that.
This part I have a problem with. NFL teams still seem to be trying to minimize these issues rather than actually deal with them.

Spoiler-phobia is getting a little ridiculous these days.

*Better Call Saul* (April 10, AMC), *The Leftovers* (April 16, HBO), and *Fargo* (April 19, FX) return with two weeks of each other, and will be running at the same time as *The Americans* and Ryan Murphys *Feud*, which premiere over the next couple weeks...
13-episode Hugh Hefner documentary titled *American Playboy* (April 7, Amazon), *Handmaids Tale* (April 26, Hulu) and an adaptation of Neil Gaimans *American Gods* (Starz, April 30)...
*Archer* (April 5, FXX), *Angie Tribeca* (TBS, April 10), *Brooklyn Nine-Nine*, *Veep* (April 16, HBO), *Silicon Valley*, and *Catastrophe* (April 28, Amazon)...
Need a little nostalgia fix? How about a *Prison Break* revival (April 4, Fox), all-new episodes of *Mystery Science Theater 3000* (April 14, Netflix), and Peter Capaldis final season on *Doctor Who*...
I still havent mentioned *iZombie* (April 4, The CW) or *The Get Down* (April 7, Netflix) or *Bosch* (April 21, Amazon) or about a dozen other shows.

The big earners are predominantly huge blockbusters that likely would have made the same amount of money regardless of the cast's diversity. Would fewer people have seen The Force Awakens if Finn were played by Alden Ehrenreich instead of John Boyega?
I don't really see what you're getting at...Are you implying that a large portion of the diverse films are blockbusters (and following along, big network TV shows)? Do you have any proof of that?
Also, how confident are you really that blockbusters aren't reactive to this reported correlation? *If 'Star Wars' had a less diverse cast, would the same amount of people have bought tickets for it?* I'd guess no, honestly.
Did you read the rest of the article? Movies and TV with more diverse casts make more money, on average.

WRITING.TEXT: Is that a good number, all things considered?
I suppose it was a reactionary attempt to relay my confusion about how this community operates, TechnoHorse.

The questions a person might have: Did this person watch the show or is he indifferent towards the premise?
Post title: "Big Little Lies -- Series Premiere Discussion" A person has an answer!
Why is this person indifferent?
This person doesn't fully know at the moment why he's indifferent, hence the absence of further analysis.
You want some half-baked shit right after watching the episode, of which part may be true to me, but also part parroting common critiques I've heard before, and part contrived bullshit? I could probably do that. But what if I don't? What if I only give my overall impression, which I know to be true, and let others forming their opinion on the show only be influenced by that? edit: grammar

What makes you think my immediate reasoning or analysis -- or many people's -- would be any more valuable than their overall impression? If I like a thing or don't like a thing it's first and foremost visceral.
If you say so

Fans see two actors playing best friends and can't handle it when they aren't besties in real life.
Nah. Fans see two coworkers refusing to work together because they don't like each other. Viewers of the show do it all the time in their own lives -- work alongside someone they don't like; why can't these actors?

Meh.
edit: Mine is an invalid opinion, per downvoters. Disregard
I might argue ambiguity can be a great thing, storytelling-wise.
YEAH

Oh boy..this character is more than a gender identification. The character is a character -- a person doing human-like things, having human-like emotions. Once the point is made that they identify as non-binary (it didn't happen in the character's into in 2x01 btw), you take note and move on, just as you would subconsciously the gender of a more obvious male or female character during their intro. edit: spelling

It depends how they're told -- look at *Transparent* for a well-done version -- but I think it's a few things: (1) These shows are everywhere. TV has done nothing if not disproportionately house the stories of very well-off white people, in the name of aspiration. (2) It's not always easy for viewers to empathize with "problems" that they themselves would jump at the opportunity to have.
I'm sure there's an envy aspect as well behind some folks' dislike, but setting that aside, this stuff simply gets old.

When the two characters all of a sudden go from being good friends to never appearing on screen together again, for multiple seasons (despite both remaining a show which required them to communicate with each other every once in a while), it became at the very least, curious
No

We did often, still, IIRC. But to the degree that it decreased it was due to Ish, and his diminutive stature. He's a tiny 5-11, 175 lbs, which isn't going to match up well vs. most 2s or 3s. He's more than 30 lbs lighter and has 7-8 inches less wingspan than Jackson.

Drummond hasn't improved since his rookie year, really. It's a big problem.

It sounded like that's what Lowe thinks they should do, at least partially, but the Pistons would refuse. New arena, playoff mandate and all
I agree with that, though. There's not much upside with this group, and they're about to enter the tax. I'm not saying trade Drummond, but get Stanley involved more, try and aim for a pick around 10 in this upcoming stacked draft.

Caldwell-Pope also does that because he's *really* good at it. He's one of the best individual PG-defenders in the NBA. Combine that with Reggie having the size/length to match up against 2s and it makes a lot of sense, even without factoring in Jackson's overall caliber defensively.
If KCP wasn't crossmatching on the plethora of PGs that dominate the NBA today he wouldn't be nearly as valuable a player. I doubt he'd want that.

That's a small solace. Drummond always says the right things, btw; it has portended *zero* about how things have worked out on the court. Reggie and Andre being buds doesn't mean anything if they continue to play how they're playing.

WRITING.TEXT: Site moving super slow for anyone else?

I'll agree, it doesn't make a ton of sense on the surface; and this is coming from a guy who doesn't think as much of Ebron as probably most here. I'm just saying, that's what's out there right now, from multiple analysts (Jeremiah is as respected as they come, draft-wise, and has lots of legit connections; Risdon's all-too-eager-to-offer rumors I take with a huge grain of salt), and anything is possible. If the Lions have a really solid plan in place to reform their offensive system to one based predominantly out of 12-personnel sets ([not too common these days](https://www.instagram.com/p/BO6Gzr1DwgU/)), there might be a way to make this work. If they do it, Howard makes far more sense than Njoku given the former's blocking ability, but I'm just short of completely ruling it out.

He'll be cheap, sign him up and see what he can offer. He's up to 255 lbs now, is still young, and has some talent. No, he's not a blocking TE, but the Lions will damn sure have room for useful players if he can prove himself as that, in his role.
P.S. I refuse to believe that he's a worse blocker than Eric Ebron, who has to be the worst blocking tight end I have ever seen at the NFL level. (I think that more than anything is driving this TE-need talk surrounding the Lions.)
